Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A virtual role-playing simulation for social emotional learning using artificially intelligent characters and crowdsourcing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project will develop novel 3D web and mobile role-playing simulations that can improve social skills in children. Virtual characters participate in nuanced conversations with students, powering a transformational experience for practicing and assessing communication skills. Rigorous evaluations have demonstrated the feasibility and efficacy of teaching perspective-taking and social skills through simulated role-playing, beneficial to students struggling with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), or bullying. These simulations will disrupt the multi-billion dollar market for social emotional learning (SEL) by allowing students to learn and practice social skills as they would with teachers or therapists, but at a fraction of the cost. Current solutions for practicing and assessing social skills rely on face-to-face interaction, which is costly and difficult to scale. Producing socially rich, open-ended simulations has previously been infeasible, due to technical challenges required to replicate the complexity of human language. This project overcomes these barriers using an innovative technology with the potential to revolutionize how people learn and practice social skills by delivering real-time personalized feedback at scale. Future applications of the social behavior capture (So-Cap) technology that underlies this project range from contextually aware intelligent personal assistants to socially aware robotics.

This project's unprecedented ability to respond authentically to open-ended natural language input relies on an innovative crowdsourced approach to artificial intelligence (AI), which imbues machines with the ability to understand dialogue in context and engage in extended conversations covering multiple topics. Individualized responses are tailored to user input by drawing from a massive database of recorded human dialogue, captured from online role-playing. The process for mining meaningful patterns from this data also employs crowdsourcing, relying on non-experts hired online to cluster and annotate words, utterances, and events. A computational model formed by these patterns powers a real-time conversational engine, which selects responses by combining AI techniques including plan recognition and case-based planning. The goal of this research is to pioneer a practical, repeatable process for democratizing the production of social simulations, minimizing cost while maximizing societal impact by providing social skills practice at scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mission of Giant Otter Technologies is to use conversational artificial intelligence (AI) to improve people’s lives. This Small Business Innovation Research grant funded research and development efforts that would build on Dr. Jeff Orkin’s invention at MIT of a breakthrough in simulating social interaction and dialogue, and apply the new approach to commercially relevant and socially beneficial problems.

The core innovation of Giant Otter is a novel human-machine collaborative approach to conversational systems that enables faster, lower cost development and better performance, especially for extended interactions. At the end of Phase I, we had developed the software to implement our runtime conversation engine, connected the engine to a virtual game world, and showed that it could drive a simulation of a social interaction that could positively impact behavior in the children who played it. But the process and tools to create the AI model behind the simulation were primitive, and therefore the pace of content creation was limited. In addition the runtime engine was not scalable to many simultaneous users, and the game that we produced wasn’t packaged as a polished product - for example, it was only offered as a web application, not downloadable and not available for mobile.

The Phase II research addressed these issues and produced SchoolLife, a scalable, secure, polished, and content-rich 3D game product, with five separate extended, open-ended AI interactions. The interactions are built around the challenge of identifying and responding productively to bullying behavior in a middle school setting. Bystanders are the target of much anti-bullying intervention efforts, as they can act as circuit breakers to interrupt recurring abusive behaviors. But standing up and finding the words to intervene with a bully, a victim, a teacher or one’s peers can be daunting. SchoolLife gives kids the opportunity to practice those challenging conversations repeatedly, and get real-time coaching to build the confidence to be an effective bystander when it matters.

With the TECP and Phase IIB supplements, we extended Giant Otter’s reach beyond virtual worlds, to text messaging and voice platforms. These platforms were natural extensions as they have experienced tremendous growth in usage over the past few years. In addition, they appeal more to adult users, opening opportunities leverage our conversational AI capabilities for business applications. Social skills are not just important in K-12 school settings; they are critical to many jobs, especially frontline roles in sales and customer service. Our TrueTalk product connects our AI to the phone system, and the voice-based simulations feel like a real phone call with a prospect or customer. It revolutionizes the new hire training process, multiplying the number of hours of dedicated practice that each employee gets, and transforming the productivity of call centers and large sales teams.

Both supplements also supported streamlining our content authoring framework known as Express. Partnering with Google Research, we added more pre-trained features and models to speed up the annotation and clustering tasks, for example, by predicting cluster matches. And under the IIB extension, we developed new web-based tools to complete our end-to-end data pipeline and eliminate any offline tasks in text files and spreadsheets; the result is a better controlled and faster process from seed transcripts to bots.

Over the past three years, chatbots and voice assistants have exploded in popularity. It has become obvious that the future will bring more and more devices and software that we will interact with in natural language. But with the current, competing natural language AI frameworks, they won’t get very far beyond recreating the command line. The Phase II SBIR (and supplements) played a key role in positioning Giant Otter to capitalize on our unique strengths in conversational systems that support extended, open-ended, realistic interactions. There is a huge opportunity in front of Giant Otter. And it was only possible with the years of support from the NSF - for the most part before this technology was on everyone’s radar.
